In the near future, Rose hopes to be among the famous boutique owners in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Marie Christelle's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est composé de 8 femmes ayant une bonne cohésion sociale et exerçant pratiquement la même activité, qui est le commerce.
Debout à droite de la photo et levant la main, Marie est âgée de 47 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 2 filles, elle a aussi en charge 2 autres enfants.  
Le prêt reçu va lui permettre de mener son activité commerciale, ainsi elle compte acheter 10 sacs de pain de singe, 10 sacs de bissap et du sucre et divers ingrédients nécessaire  pour le jus.
Avec les bénéfices générés elle assure et participe à la scolarité de ses enfants. Elle soutient aussi son fils malade dans ses frais médicaux.
texts.en:
This group is made up of eight women who are all friends and engage in commerce. Standing on the right in the photo with her hand raised is Marie, who is 47 years old. She is married and a mother of five children, two of whom are girls. She also takes care of two other children. 

This loan will allow her to conduct her business. She hopes to buy 10 sacs of baobab fruit, 10 sacs of bissap, sugar, and other various ingredients needed to make juice. 

With the earnings, Marie contributes to her children's schooling. She also pays for her sick son's medical expenses.

loans.use: to buy baobab fruit, bissap, and sugar

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is home to the main campus of Moi University. He has four children and has been doing this work for seven years. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, transportation services and a personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Earning from sale of milk." He said that his biggest challenge is poor infrastructure in the area in terms of the road network that thus increases transport costs. Animals on the farm have not been named.

Daniel was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Was introduced to Juhudi Kilimo by group members." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "Learnt how microfinance Institutions work to finance farmers to improve their livelihoods."

His highest monthly expense is transportation costs. When asked how this loan would benefit his family, Daniel replied 'he will purchase a dairy cow to increase production.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Daniel owns the following: cows, poultry and motorcycle, but does not own pigs, a pump, bicycles or automobiles. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV or DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is home to the main campus of Moi University. She has two children and her primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business. She has been doing this work for four years.
 
She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Rearing dairy cows for milk production." Her biggest challenge is "Milk price fluctuation, poor road network, low yielding dairy breed, and lack of finances." Animals on the farm have not been given names.

Nancy was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied that she "joined Juhudi group after being convinced by a group member."  

This client was also asked what she learned during Juhudi's required microfinance training session: "Learnt how microfinance Institutions work to boost farmers' production through offering financial support."

Her highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked how this loan would benefit her family, Nancy replied: "Will purchase dairy animal."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Nancy owns the following: cow, poultry. She does not own pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile.

Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net and TV, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is a primary milk-producing area. She has four children and has been doing this work for three years.  Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and her personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Earning from agriculture.' Her biggest challenge is 'Access to financial services is a problem.' An animal on the farm has been given the name of 'Murgusi.'

Everlyne was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Joined Juhudi after being introduced by a neighbour who belongs to the group.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Learnt how i could boost income through agricultural projects financed by the Micro Finance Institution.'

Her highest monthly expense is family expenses. When asked 'How will this loan benefit her family', Everlyne replied 'Will start a poultry project to boost income generation.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Everlyne owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, or DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down."

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Fatou Mbaye's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe a été le 19 Décembre 2004. Il est composé de femmes ayant une bonne cohésion de groupe et une solidarité dynamique. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce. 

Debout à droite de la photo la vedette Anna est âgée de 48 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants dont 03 garçons et une fille. 

Avec le prêt reçu, elle achète de l'huile de palme à 850 frs le litre, du poisson sec à 600 frs le kg, du jus de citron à 500 frs le litre pour revendre à 1500 frs l'huile de palme, 1000 frs le kg de poisson ses et 750 frs le litre de jus de citron. 
Elle paie le transport et les taxes au niveau des eaux et forêts à 20 000 frs. 

Les bénéfices générés par son activités lui permettent de renforcer sa marchandise et d'appuyer ses enfants dans leur scolarité.
texts.en:
This group was created on December 19, 2004.  It is made up of some dynamic women who are very united as a group and who are showing a high level of solidarity.  Their main activity is small retail.

The featured borrower, Anna, is 48 years old.  She is standing at the right-hand side of the photo.  She is married and the mother of four children, three boys and a girl.

She is using her loan to buy some palm oil (at a cost of 850 francs per liter), some dry fish (600 francs per kilo) and lemon juice (500 francs per liter).  She will resell the palm oil at a price of 1,500 francs per liter, the dry fish at a price of 1,000 francs per kilo and the lemon juice at a price of 750 francs per liter.  She spends 20,000 francs for transportation and for water and forestry taxes.

With the profits from her business, she is able to increase her stock of goods and to contribute to her children's education.

loans.use: to buy oil, fish and lemon juice for resale.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James was born in Kaya village, Siaya County, in Western Kneya. He is married with children and is engaged in retail small scale business. James wants to make a difference in his community and town of Siaya by engaging community health outreach programme run by a Community Based Organization CBO in the district. He has also committed to spend most of his free time with the CHW counseling the youth on avoiding anti social practices, drug abuse and AIDs/HIV prevention. James is happy to own his own motorcycle and is ready to give back to the community the free tranport services to CHW. James will also use the income generated from his motorcycle business to support his family he plans to buy another motorcycle and support more CHWs and other community work in future

loans.use: To Purchase a Motorcycle to Support Community Health Workers and for Micro-Transport Business

loans.name: Triunfadoras Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Angelica is 40 years old, married, and with a young son in elementary school. She
lives in a section of the municipality of Nicolas Romero denominated Pozo Azul (Blue Well) which, unlike
the verdant depiction its name gives, is a neighborhood with dry, unpaved, dusty roads and public
transportation that is infrequent at best. In this zone, detached from the center of town, the people rely
on local businesses to attain necessary goods and services for quotidian life, as well as the occasional
luxury item like the latest DVD or a new pair of shoes. Many members of the Pozo Azul community
know each other since their lives revolve in large part around the local schools and well-being of their
children. This is how the group of neighbors came together and began working with Podemos Progresar
in order to advance their businesses and better serve the necessities of their own community. The group
has named itself Triunfadoras (Triumphant Ones) and their businesses include stationary shops, food
stores, and hand-manufactured textiles products -- such as curtains and dresses. Angelica in particular
has a store, which for 5 years she has run from the front room of her house, where she sells plates,
cleaning supplies, and plastic storage ware. On her property in front of the main house she has a room
in the final stages of construction where she plans to relocate her supplies and finally move her store
outside of her house. Given that her husband Jesus (also in the group) has 23 years of experience as
a construction worker he works hard to make daily advances on the construction of this new building
when he himself is not busy attending to his tiny food store and small stationary shop which also
consists of one computer with internet access and a copier machine (both stores also located in another
section of their house). Angelica asked for $4000 pesos in order to finally finish the construction of her
new locale and to obtain more merchandise. With these investments Angelica will be able to better
establish her business and better grow the products and services she can offer her community while
increasing her economic standing and entrepreneurial vision.

loans.use: to buy inventory for their business

loans.name: Arcoiris Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Adriana is a 56 year old widow with her own house who only finished elementary
school. She has sold clothes through a catalog house by house to many of her friends and business
contacts for the past 2 years as a way to have economic independence and have a more-or-less stable
income. In addition to this she puts into action the sewing skills she acquired while growing up to make
shawls, napkins, and other sewn trinkets depending on the demand by her clients for special occasions.
However, these two business ventures lay on the periphery of what she most enjoys and capitalizes on
-- baking cookies. Adriana sells her cookies from house to house in her neighborhood and surrounding
areas, both to old clients and new zones. This helps her gain new contacts not only for selling her
cookies but also for creating relationships to offer her sewn handiwork and her clothes catalog. Many of
her cookies also sell due to their delicious reputation and word-of-mouth advertising among her current
clients. The largest cookie batches Adriana sells are for special holidays and events such as Children's
Day, Mother's Day, and upcoming Teacher's Day. She usually average around 25 half-kilo boxes of her
cookies on the days she bakes for these special occasions, which is an impressive feat given that she
does not have a large industry-sized oven, but rather a smaller family-sized oven where she used to
prepare her family's meals when they lived with her and can only bake one tray at a time. The loan
for $4000 pesos Adriana is asking for will mostly be for purchasing raw material for her cookies and
to invest in the clothes she sells, but she plans to eventually be able to buy a larger oven to grow her
cookie business and maybe in the distant future grow enough to have an establishment and have her
clients come to her. These are the entrepreneurial dreams that keep her going and although the road
will be a long one for Adriana, every scrumptious box of cookies sold or clothes order placed for another
satisfied customer will take her one step closer.

loans.use: buy inventory

loans.name: Gevans  Luyo

texts.en: Gevans was born in Kwisero in Kakamega County. He has a family and supports his siblings from income gained from renting a motorcycle in town. He has been riding a rented bike for two years. At times Gevans gets many customers, especially during the market days, when he has to transport people and produce to the main market. Gevans wants to acquire his own bike in order to support his community and provide for his family. He is well aware of activities of Community Health Workers (CHWs) in his community and will assist in providing transport to CHWs working for a local community organization. Distances between homesteads in Kwisero can be very long and transportation support to CHWS will save time. His family is excited and happy that Gevans can have a motorbike of his own. He hopes to introduce other members of his social club to this program.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to support Community Health Workers and for transport business

loans.name: Agustine

texts.en: Augustine was born in Kolwa west Kisumu District. He has been doing business using a rented motorcycle for for two years. He is married with two children and he is happy to own his own bike. Augustine has committed to provide transport to CHWs targeting the youth and prevention of drug abuse. He is also interested in supporting youth groups counseling and positive living. The motorcycle will enable Augustine provide for his family and support the community as well. He hopes to encourage other motorcycle taxi drivers enroll in the CHW support programme in order to adequately cover all remote locations of Kisumu county. Augustine is an experienced motorcycle taxi trader and he hopes to make money and buy another motorcycle and support two CHWs.

loans.use: To Purchase Motorcycle to Support Community Health Workers and Micro Business

loans.name: Erastus

texts.en: Erastus has been renting a motorcycle for micro-business work for three years. He is married with two children and lives in a heavily populated suburb of Kisumu City. Erastus has committed to provide transport to CHWs targeting youth groups and patients. Erastus says owning the bike is great but supporting his community is greater. Ersatus should also be able to grow his business and provide for his family. He belongs to a business association and hopes to encourage many more members to join in supporting the CHW work in Kisumu City

loans.use: To Purchase Motorcycle to Support Community Health Workers and for Motorcycle Taxi

loans.name: Micheal

texts.en: Micheal is a 36-year-old hardworking married man with 2 children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is in the transport business, and the business is lucrative despite challenges of bad roads and high fuel costs. He is a good father and desires to educate his children up to the university level and to set up sustainable income generating activities for them. Micheal intends to use the loan to buy land for farming.

loans.use: to buy land for farming.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James was born in Kaya village, Siaya County. In western Kenya. He is married with children and is engaged in retail small scale business. James wants to make a difference in his community and town of Siaya by engaging community health outreach programme run by a Community Based Organization CBO in the district. He has also committed to spend most of his free time with the CHW counseling the youth on avoiding anti social practices, drug abuse and AIDs/HIV prevention. James is happy to own his own motorcycle and is ready to give back to the community the free tranport services to CHW.  James will also use the income generated from his motorcycle business to support his family, he plans to buy another motorcycle and support more CHWs and other community work in future.

loans.use: To Purchase a Motorcycle to Support Community Health Workers and for Micro-Business

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 2 years, Salama has been working hard to manage her vegetable-selling business. 

To help expand her business, Salama has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more different vegetables to sell, and will help Salama to generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. Salama hopes that in the future she will be able to build a residential house. 

Salama is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more more different vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. He has no children.

His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business, and he has been doing this work for three years. 

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Poultry keeping." His biggest challenge is "poultry diseases." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Maua."

Silas was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Because Juhudi Kilimo finances farmers." This client was also asked what he learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "They are short-term loans for small-scale farmers and businesses."

His highest monthly expense is business related. When asked how this loan will benefit his family, Silas replied that he "will be able to educate my brothers and sisters."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Silas owns the following: cow and poultry, but does not own pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down."

loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Fravia's Group

texts.en:
Fravia's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Fravia is 19 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past 2 years, Fravia has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells mobile phones. 

To help expand her business, Fravia has requested a loan of 700000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more mobile phones to sell, and will help Fravia to generate greater profits and take care of her children and her family. Fravia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Fravia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more mobile phones to sell

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher used the previous loan to buy a motorcycle. He is a 35-year-old married man with three children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. Although he never went to school, Christopher has a vision of educating his children up to university. For seven years, he has been in the transport sector. He started as a hired driver and, after accumulating enough wages, Christopher bought his own motorcycle and has found the sector to be very lucrative. He faces the hardships of high fuel and transportation costs. His vision is to diversify his business to include dairy farming and to own at least six motorcycles. 

Christopher is requesting a loan to buy a new motorcycle that he intends to hire out to a second person who will be remitting 80% of the daily earnings.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce has operated a clothing shop for a number of years. Her potential clients are ladies and gentlemen. She mentions the varying seasons as being a challenge for her business, and dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the 50,000 KES loan, Joyce will purchase clothing for men, women, and children for resale for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for men, women, and children for resale

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby in addition to that she also does a business of selling (khangas)women wrap cloth to supplement her earnings. Her potential customers are neighbors, pupils and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the loan that she is requesting, she wants to purchase a stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a Kiva borrower who has borrowed a loan of KES 12,000 from SMEP DTM. She will use the money to buy a water tank to store water, since she has been travelling a long distance to get water.

Grace describes herself to be committed. She runs a shop where she sells fruits, sugar, salt and other items as a source of income. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan was paid successfully.

loans.use: to purchase a water tank.

loans.name: Miranda

texts.en:
Miranda is applying for a loan for the first time; she wants to increase the income by buying another dairy cow. She sells milk to the local market of a nearby city.

Miranda is 28 years old and married and has a seven-year-old child. She lives in the southeastern Albania and practices livestock activity. 

“I started five years back, and I haven’t got bored of it yet,” she said with a smile. “Even if I got bored, there is nothing better I could do, so, all in all it’s okay. I have gotten used to the daily routine now” she continued saying with laughter.

loans.use: to add another milk cow

loans.name: Hatixhe

texts.en:
Hatixhe is a mother of five children who lives in a village in southeastern Albania. Her living condition is below the poverty level and has been such “for as long as I remember” according to Hatixhe. 

“I kept praying that someday I would be given an opportunity or some sort of help from someone, and my prayers were answered when I was told that VFA, in collaboration with WVA, was running the value chain project in my village. I was so happy that finally I would buy a cow and sell the milk from it for a little income. I have another cow, but I use it to feed my family,” Hatixhe said.

Hatixhe will use lenders’ financial help to purchase a cow. She wants to thank them for their help.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Aleko

texts.en:
Aleko has been operating a little restaurant where he serves traditional foods from his region and also has been in the agricultural field for long time. Note here that Aleko is being dressed up and not photographed at his business because he was taken this shot just before some sudden trip. The field in the background though is his and is prepared for planting.
“I love cooking our regions specialty and luckily we have plenty,” Aleko said. “I also cultivate potatoes that my region is known for the best potato produce in our country and then sell them to wholesalers from another region. I have been working hard on both of my businesses and have faced difficulties for sure,” he continued.
Aleko is requesting this loan for the first time to buy potato seeds.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds for planting

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick was born in Amerikwa Village in Teso South. He is married and has a family. Patrick has been involved in a small-scale motorcycle business for four years in Busia town, close to the border between Kenya and Uganda. Patrick wants to own a motorcycle to support the community health work in his community and make a difference and expand his micro business as well. Patrick will link with a Community Health Worker (CHW) working in his community and will support the community health worker by providing transport on set days. This will give much-needed capacity to the CHW to be able to reach many more families during counseling appointments and health visits. Patrick hopes to recruit other members of his small business organization to join in supporting community health outreach programs in Teso community. Patrick will also use the income generated from his motorcycle taxi business to support his family. He hopes to become a CHW volunteer in his community once he has finished paying for his motorcycle

loans.use: To purchase a motocycle for community health work and taxi business

loans.name: Munkhbaatar

texts.en:
Munkhbaatar is a married man who lives with his spouse and son in an apartment. He is a teacher at a university and his wife is a receptionist at another university while his son attends university. Munkhbaatar has a seven-room dormitory and now four of them are empty. The other three have residents. 

He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to set up a heating system in his dormitory. Since the weather is very changeable, if he sets up a heating system the dormitory will be more comfortable for his residents. In the future, he wants to have long-term trusted residents.

loans.use: to set up a heating system in his dormitory.

loans.name: Enkhtsetseg

texts.en:
Enkhtsetseg is a 48-year-old widow who lives with her two daughters, ages 23 and 26, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the outer ger districts of the city. Her younger daughter is a student while her older daughter helps with her business. 

Enkhtsetseg supports her family by operating a shoe retail stall at the largest outdoor market and also two other indoor markets in Mongolia, with help from her elder daughter. 

When she first began her business in 2002, Enkhtsetseg was a contracted seller of a local shoe factory and she didn't have her own working capital. As a result of her hard work, today she has 6.5 million Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) in working capital at her stall. During the past 10 years, she has gained a lot of experience and she has been able to improve her living conditions. 

She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to import goods from Beijing for the upcoming season.

loans.use: to purchase goods to sell for the upcoming season.

loans.name: Gaddy

texts.fr:
NAHIMANA a 45 ans, il est marrie, il a 8 enfants dont le plus grand a 21 ans et le plus petit a 2 ans. 7 enfants vont à l`école.NAHIMANA a étudie 3 école sécondaire.

Il sillicite ce crédit pour acheter la parcel .il n`attend aucune difficultes pour le remboursement.

Ses ambitions est d`avoir sa propre maison et éduquer ses enfants.
texts.en:
GASANA is 45 years old and married. He has eight children. The eldest is 21, the youngest is 2. Seven of them attend school. GASANA has three years of secondary education.

He's seeking this loan to buy a land lot. He does not foresee any difficulty in repaying the loan. He ambitions to have his own house and educate his children.

loans.use: to buy a land lot

loans.name: Oyunsuvdiin Buleg Group

texts.en:
Oyunsuvd is a-30-year-old lady who lives with her family in an outer ger district of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. She started her felt manufacturing business in 2004. She makes felt sandals, felt souvenirs and other products which tourists traveling in Mongolia are interested in buying. In July, Mongolians have the great holiday Naadam, so during this holiday a lot of tourists come to Mongolia. Thus she needs to make more felt products.

Oyunsuvd is requesting a Kiva loan with Transcapital NBFI from Mongolia. This loan will be used to purchase raw materials in order to make more felt products and increase her income during the Naadam holiday.  This loan is their second Kiva loan.

loans.use: to purchase more felt to make more products.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Even though Akosua grew up in poverty without an education, she has managed to fulfill her dream of making a better life for her and her family. Akosua is an entrepreneur, selling sandals in Mankessim Estate, near Cape Coast. Her business has grown a lot since she began six years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their four children. 

Akosua has worked out that there are growing demands among consumers for her shoes. However, she is not able to meet this demand because of limited inventory capacity. She has asked for a loan to buy more sandals to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Akosua wants make sure that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to buy more sandals to sell

loans.name: Manuel Concepcion

texts.es:
El socio se sigue dedicando al negoco de restaurant,el socio prepara desayunos,almuerzos y cenas,el socio tambien vende chicha de jora que es una bebida a base de maiz,el socio tambien vende frutillada,el socio ya tiene 7 años en este negocio y le va muy bien,el sueño del socio es ampliar el restaurant.El socio solicita el credito para comprar carne,pollo,arroz y verduras.

El socio se siente agradecido por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This member continues working in his restaurant where he prepares breakfasts, lunches and dinners.  He also sells chicha, which is a fermented corn-based drink.  He also sells frutillada, a fermented corn-based drink that contains strawberry.  He has worked in this business for 7 years and it is going very well.  His dream is to grow his restaurant.  He is seeking this loan so that he can buy meat, chicken, rice and vegetables.

He is very thankful for this loan and promises to comply with the re-payment terms.

loans.use: to buy meat, chicken, rice, and vegetables.

loans.name: Tsend

texts.en:
Borrower Mr.Tsend is 30 years old married man who lives with his wife, son and daughter, father and mother in apartment. His son attends kindergarten while daughter stays at home. He supports his family by operating clothing stall business with his wife at local indoor market. Besides clothing stall he also operates Pub. 

He is a very hardworking guy since he operates two kind of business and now he is preparing to go Guangjou, China in order to import summer clothes. Thus he is requesting a 3.000.000 MNT loan to purchase summer fashionable clothes for upcoming season.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell for upcoming season.

loans.name: Enkhbaatar

texts.en:
Enkhbaatar is a 53-year-old retired paymaster, who lives with his spouse and daughter in the outer ger district of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia, which lacks basic infrastructure. His daughter is a teacher who specializes in psychology. 

His current house was built 11 years ago. His house was needed renovation, because the house has become old and poor. His previous Kiva loan was disbursed to re-cover the roof and then enlarge the storeroom (depot) and do some interior work before the rainy season.  

Now Enkhbaatar is requesting a MNT 3,000,000 (Mongolian Tugrik) loan to finish his housing project which last year he couldn't finished.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials in order to finish his housing project

loans.name: Neslie

texts.en:
This is Neslie. She previously accessed a 12,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, house hold and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 12,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Neslie dreams of continuous growth in her business and hopes to give her children a good life and future.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Lizete

texts.en: Lizete is applying for a loan of $1,000 to repair her car. She is married and she has three children. She is using the loan to buy tires, oil, fuel and the items that needed for car to be repaired. Her husband is a driver and uses the car to carry the passengers from the town where they live to the market. She is happy with TRM (Tuba Rai Metin) that offered loan for poor people.

loans.use: To buy a mini bus

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Borrower Ms. Dolgorsuren is a 41-year-old married woman who lives with her family in an outer ger district, which lacks basic city infrastructure. She works as an attendant and her hubby works in a private company. She lives with her husband, two daughters and a grandchild. The current house in which the family lives is very old and needs some repair work, so she is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase the necessary housing materials. She desires to finish her housing project this summer and live happily with her family there.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials and to finish her housing project

loans.name: Erdenebaatar

texts.en:
Borrower Mr.Erdenebaatar is years old married man who lives with his family in apartment which he bought recently by his income. He works at local company while his wife works as a sales assistant at the biggest Expo center of the city. Besides his current job he operates home and office furniture selling business. He said: "Nowadays its really hard to live only salary income, so I decided to own a business". 

He is requesting a 3.000.000 MNT loan to purchase more furniture to sell and increase his family income in order to live with his family happily and successfully.

loans.use: to purchase more furnitures to sell

loans.name: Batkhurel

texts.en:
Borrower Batkhurel is  49 years old married man and lives with his wife and son in outer ger district which lacks basic infrastructure of the city. As usual now its the housing projects season Batkhurel also decided to make some renovation work and housing project at his current old house.

He is requesting a 3.000.000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials in order to finish his housing project. He is a hardworking person who is willing to make better living condition to his family.

loans.use: to make housing project at his current house

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
Borrower Ms.Tserendolgor is years old married woman who lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. She is a head of the local construction company, her company makes interior and exterior design of the buildings and also builds property by a subscription. 

She needs some construction materials to continue her job thus she is requesting a 3.000.000 MNT loan to purchase necessary construction materials. She will pay her loan by an income which will transfer after when she finishes her work.

loans.use: to purchse construction materials

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Borrower Ms. Otgonbayar is a 40-year-old, married woman who has three children. She lives with her family in the outer Ger district, which lacks the basic infrastructure of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her eldest two children attend secondary school and the other attends a local kindergarten. 

She supports her family by operating a retail stall business. Currently, she has approximately 4,500,000 MNT in working capital. She really wants to increase her working capital by applying a 2,000,000 MNT Kiva loan through Transcapital MFI. She is a very hardworking and ambitious woman who desires to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell in order to increase her working capital

loans.name: Faapaia

texts.en:
"Faapaia is a 28 year old married woman with 2 children. 
She has a small plantation and grows taro, bananas and yams to earn a living. She has been doing this for 5 years.Faapaia has requested a loan to buy wheelbarrow, manure chemicals,week killer and bushknives.She has been a member of SBPD in 2013.With her profits,Faapaia hopes to help support her family and her children's education.

loans.use: to buy wheelbarrow, manure chemicals,week killer and bushknives

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter operates a farming business. He describes himself as an honest man with a future goal to succeed in business and purchase a lorry to transport food crops to the market. He is applying for a loan of KES 25,000 that will be used to purchase a water tank. Challenges he faces include inadequate water storage facilities for his farm for irrigation. This will be his 3rd successive loan application with SMEP DTM, with his previous loan being KES 30,000.

loans.use: To purchase a a water tank.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is applying for a kes 21,000 loan to purchase a water tank. It will benefit 6 family members in his area. He also operates a retail store.

loans.use: to purchase a water tank.

loans.name: Benedict

texts.en: Benedict is a 58-year-old married man with six children. The eldest is 35, and the youngest is 19. He is applying for a loan of 59,000 KES which will be used to purchase a water tank. This project will benefit 15 people and will take 2 weeks to complete. A challenge he faces in his area is the lack of sufficient water to use in cultivation and for human consumption. This will be his third successive loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank.

loans.name: Tracy

texts.en:
Tracy is 50 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has six children with two of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Tracy has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells rice, sugar and salt, etc. 

To help expand her business, Tracy has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale, and will help Tracy to generate greater profits and improve on her standard of living. Tracy hopes that in the future she will be able to become a powerful entrepreneur. 

Tracy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Tracy who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale
